div.p: I’m Tim Brooks. I’m the chief executive of BMJ Group. The starting for this is that
for very complex and multiple reasons government in this country has gotten way behind the
rest of the country in terms of the way it uses technology to deal with the people it
deals with, which is the citizens of this country. It’s a cliché but you can book
a flight in two minutes to anywhere in the world on a screen in your home or even on
your phone, and yet dealing with government can involve paperwork and writing a cheque
and putting something in the mail and all that kind of stuff.
At a very simple level it’s let’s make sure that government just catches up with
where its citizens find themselves in the rest of their lives. Because the danger is
not just about cost, and it’s not just about efficiency, but it’s actually about relevance
and engagement with the people who fund government. Digital buy default; you could spend a lot
of time wrestling with history and explaining the 97 reasons why things are how they are
and how they got that way. That’s just, in many respects, a complete waste of time.
So digital by default is Martha Lane Fox’s slogan that she devised and attached to the
strategy that government digital service is pursuing, and it simply means it’s digital.
If it isn’t digital, why is not digital? It’s not about let’s understand all the
reasons why we are where we are; it’s about why are we going to be so simple going forward.
The government making use of small and medium businesses is a subject close to my heart
because I actually run a medium-sized business. There’s been a lot of discussion about how
government procurement processes historically have made it extremely difficult for anything
other than very large and established suppliers to complete in this space. And yet the reality
as we know and as the government constantly highlights when they’re talking about digital
Britain, it’s often the smaller companies, you know, the digital roundabout people in
Shoreditch who might be a 20-person company, who are driving change and being really innovative
and inventing new services and taking costs out of processes. Getting those smaller companies
engaged will unleash a lot of creativity. Without being rude to systems integrators,
the big companies – and we use them ourselves when we need to – they have a very fixed
way of doing things, and it’s always a big way of doing things. Often the way to solve
these problems effectively and quickly is to find small ways to solve them.
